channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Senate Confirms Economic Adviser as Trade Representative
item.description: Michael Froman, currently a senior White House economic adviser, will lead an agency involved in two significant trade deals.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Court Rules Against Sanctions on Iranian Bank
item.description: The decision raised new questions about the country’s secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo’s First Envoy to Serbia Resigns After Two Days
item.description: Serbia and its former southern province exchanged official representatives on Monday under a push by the European Union to improve ties between the Balkan neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Muslim Women Sentenced to Hard Labor in Myanmar
item.description: A court found the women guilty of setting off a recent outbreak of sectarian violence and convicted them of “insulting religion.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Quest for Sainthood for John Paul II Said to Advance
item.description: A Vatican official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said a commission of theologians approved a miracle attributed to John Paul’s intercession.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Brazil’s Leftist Ruling Party, Born of Protests, Is Perplexed by Revolt
item.description: The governing Workers Party is watching with dismay as political corruption, bad public services and the government’s focus on lifting Brazil’s international stature through events like the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympics inspire outrage.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: While Claiming Battle Gains Against Rebels, Syria’s Assad Is Facing Currency Crisis
item.description: The Syrian pound fell 30 percent against the dollar over the weekend in panicky selling by Syrians worried it could weaken even further.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why India Trails China
item.description: A great gap between India and China is in the provision of essential public services — a failing that depresses living standards and is a persistent drag on growth.
item.dc:creator: By AMARTYA SEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Lebanon, Overrun by Syrian Refugees
item.description: A humanitarian crisis is threatening the region’s stability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NINETTE KELLEY

item.title: Obama Asks Russia to Join in Reducing Nuclear Arms
item.description: President Obama’s new disarmament goal, announced in a speech in Berlin, drew skepticism from the Kremlin and Congress alike.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Executive at Monsanto Wins Global Food Honor
item.description: Robert Fraley of Monsanto shares the prize with two other scientists prominent in the field of genetically modified crops.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK
item.media:description: Robert Fraley, who is Monsanto’s chief technology officer.

item.title: U.S. Scrambles to Save Taliban Talks After Afghan Backlash
item.description: American officials, worried about a crumbling peace process, moved to try to resolve the Afghan government’s objections to what appeared to be a publicity coup.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghan security forces escorted a captured suspected Taliban insurgent on Wednesday during an operation in the Sorkhrod district of Jalalabad province.

item.title: Turkish Liberals Turn Their Backs on Erdogan
item.description: For an urban elite, including some protesters, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to demonstrations has led to a final break that began with his intimidation of the news media.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former supporters of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan say his response to the Taksim Square protests was the final straw.

item.title: The Lede: Tear Gas Fired Outside Stadium in Brazil, but Protest Still Spreads Inside
item.description: The police in the northeastern city of Fortaleza fired tear gas and rubber bullets at an estimated 35,000 protesters, whose message was echoed by people inside the stadium and even some players.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Athens Journal: Muffling of a Voice Provokes an Outcry in Greece
item.description: Since the state broadcaster was shut down last week and its 2,600 employees fired, there has been an outpouring of solidarity, despite its long history of mismanagement and patronage.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greek’s state broadcaster, ERT, has been defiantly streaming online after being shut by the government last week.

item.title: Dolce and Gabbana Fined in Italian Tax Case
item.description: Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana were handed a suspended sentence and a fine that could reach 10 million euros for hiding income from authorities.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Stefano Gabbana, left, and Domenico Dolce in February. They face a fine that could reach 10 million euros for hiding income.

item.title: Obama Says Surveillance Helped in Case in Germany
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel seemed to confirm the president’s comments on the controversy, which has followed him on his diplomatic trip abroad.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES
item.media:description: President Obama with Chancellor Angela Merkel and Berlin's mayor, Klaus Wowereit, at Brandenburg Gate on Wednesday.

item.title: WikiLeaks Says It Is Working to Negotiate Asylum in Iceland for Snowden
item.description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said the legal and practical obstacles are under review by Edward J. Snowden’s lawyers and supporters.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: U.S. Accuses 3 Countries of Abetting Human Trafficking
item.description: Russia, China and Uzbekistan fell to the lowest ranking in the State Department’s annual report on human trafficking and forced labor.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Europe Fines Drug Companies for Delaying Generics
item.description: Antitrust regulators levied a total of $195.5 million in penalties for what they said were companies’ attempts to block a less expensive generic version of a popular antidepressant.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Flooding Damages Lourdes, French Holy Site
item.description: Visited by nearly six million Christian pilgrims every year, the site is turning to the faithful for financial relief after storms inundated the celebrated grotto and vast subterranean church.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: The flooding could hardly have come at a less opportune time for Lourdes, whose economy depends heavily on the summer tourist season.

item.title: Italian Praised for Saving Jews Now Seen as Nazi Collaborator
item.description: Information about a man celebrated for saving Jews is being removed from the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in light of evidence that the tales may be untrue.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN

item.title: Ex-Senator Feingold Chosen as Special Envoy to African Region
item.description: In choosing Russ Feingold, Secretary of State John Kerry moved to raise the profile of the Great Lakes region of Africa, which has been torn by conflict but overshadowed by other crises.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Michael Hastings, 33, Winner of Polk Award
item.description: Mr. Hastings, an intrepid war zone reporter in Afghanistan and Iraq, won a Polk Award in 2010 for his Rolling Stone magazine cover story, “The Runaway General.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Deal to Cut Bank Secrecy Stalls in Swiss Parliament
item.description: Lawmakers said they were open to alternatives, but for now rejected a plan that would allow Swiss banks to share account data with U.S. tax officials.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
